            LAND FUND PROJECT,TF040956-HONDURAS: LAND AMINISTRATION

abstracts.cdata!:
On January 3, 2006, the Inspection Panel
            received a Request for inspection related to the Land
            Administration Project in Honduras. Of particular relevance
            to the request, one of the Project components provides for
            systematic land regularization, titling and registration of
            lands, including municipal lands, urban and rural areas,
            forests, protected areas and ethnic lands. The requesters
            claim that in the design, appraisal and implementation of
            the Project the Bank did not take the rights and interests
            of the Garifuna people into consideration and, as a result,
            violated its own policies and procedures. The requesters
            fear that as a result of these failures, the land titling
            and procedures under the Project will ultimately cause the
            loss of their rights over parts of their Ethnic Lands, and
            the demise of collective property held by Garifuna
            communities in favor of individual property. However, the
            panel finds that the Project may have consequences far
            different than intended by the Indigenous Peoples
            Development Plan. The Panel finds merit in the concerns of
            Requesters that the Project may contribute to the demise of
            titles and claims to collective lands held by the Garifuna
            and indigenous peoples. Given the relative economic and
            political vulnerability of the indigenous peoples, the Panel
            finds that the safeguards provided under the Project are not
            adequate to protect the Garifuna rights over their Ethnic
            Lands in the context of Project implementation.
